_exec_summary.SummaryText:
articipation - The Chocolate Bayou Site encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  The Site promotes employee participation through different established safety programs: VPP (Voluntary Protection Program), ESALT (Employee Safety Action and Leadership Team), PSC (Process Safety Committee), ERT (Emergency Response Team) amongst others.  Other examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team and incident investigation teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of the Site prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the prevention program are documented in the employee participation plan that addresses each prevention program element. 
11.	Hot Work Permit - The Chocolate Bayou Site mitigates hot work hazards with a Safe Work Permitting Processes.
12.	Contractors - The Chocolate Bayou Site uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Site has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform Site personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to start working. The Site evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Site personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling thei

Risk Management Plan
INEOS - Chocolate Bayou Site
Executive Summary

The affiliated INEOS entities operating at the Chocolate Bayou Site are INEOS USA LLC and INEOS Oligomers LLC (collectively, hereinafter INEOS). The Chocolate Bayou Site is a stationary source subject to Clean Air Act Section 112r and 40 CFR 68.  The Chocolate Bayou Site may hereinafter be referred to as Site or facility.  INEOS is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for the employees, the public, and the environment.  INEOS has established a system to ensure the safe operation of the processes at this facility as part of this commitment. The RMP (Risk Management Program) is a part of this system that not only intends to manage the risks and/or hazards of the processes but also complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's Regulation 40 §CFR 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: the RMP rule. This executive summary is to comply with the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP Rule (40 CFR §68.150 through 40 CFR §68.185).  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies  
INEOS is committed to the welfare of its employees, the public, and to the preservation of the environment. INEOS implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, INEOS will conduct emergency response action to help prevent or minimize injury to the public and the environment.  

Description of Facility/Regulated substances handled
INEOS - Chocolate Bayou Site manufactures polypropylene plastic and olefins, including ethylene, propylene, and butadiene through the RMP processes 1 to 7, that are submitted in this RMP. These processes are operated by INEOS USA LLC. Twenty-seven different flammable substances are held over the threshold quantity. All are hydrocarbons, ranging from hydrogen to pentane. Some substances are present at site in their pure form, such as butadiene. Most substanc

leting this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After the new operator demonstrates (i.e. through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All of this training is documented, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 
5.	Mechanical Integrity - The Chocolate Bayou Site has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures and plans, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  These activities make up a system that maintains the integrity of the process equipment.
6.	Management of Change (MOC) - The Chocolate Bayou Site utilizes a change management tool to ensure proper reviews are conducted, hazards are assessed, and a safe operation environment is maintained during and after the introduction of a change in the covered processes.  Each MOC (permanent or temporary) includes a risk assessment to identify potential hazards of a change such as (1) process equipment, (2) chemicals, (4) technology (including process operating conditions), and other facility changes.  The MOC system ensures that all documentation is updated and training completed prior to the commissioning of the change.  Approval and action items are tracked in the MOC application.
7.	Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) - Th

r safety obligations. 

Emergency Response
The Chocolate Bayou Site has a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP Rule and other federal contingency plans.   The site has its own volunteer fire brigade to respond to emergencies. Personnel receive training in responding to industrial fires and other emergencies. The facility periodically conducts drills of the emergency response system.  Emergency response is also coordinated with the LEPC.

Five-year accident history
There have been no accidents in the past five years at the facility which meet the reporting criteria of the RMP rule. 
Planned changes to improve safety
The INEOS Olefins and Polymers risk assessment process uses Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) to systematically assess risk and continually improve event detection and mitigation. Capital projects are continually identified and implemented through this risk assessment process.

e Chocolate Bayou Site conducts a PSSR for any new or modified facility that requires a change in the process safety information. This review confirms that (1) proper equipment is used, (2) that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are updated, (3) a risk assessment is conducted and (4) training has been implemented. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.
8.	Compliance Audits - The Chocolate Bayou Site performs PSM and RMP compliance audits at least every three (3) years. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports along with the resolution of findings are retained.
9.	Incident Investigation - The Chocolate Bayou Site investigates all incidents that reasonably could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  The incident investigation procedure requires an investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, identify the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards results to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years, so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.
10.	Employee P

es are present at the site in flammable mixtures of various components. The site also has aqueous ammonia (conc. 20% or greater) that is considered a toxic substance. The aqueous ammonia inventory is over the threshold quantity. INEOS Oligomers USA LLC operates process 8, Linear Alpha Olefins Unit (LAO). This unit/process manufactures heavier olefins that range from 1-hexene (C6H2) to 1-tetracosene (C24H48).  This process has three (3) flammable substances: ethylene (no storage), 1-butene and propylene.

This RMP Plan resubmission is to cover the following change at the site: 

¿	New Process 9 - Poly Alpha Olefins (PAO) Unit, operated by INEOS Oligomers USA LLC.  This unit/process is being incorporated to the RMP plan to comply with §68.190(b)(4) No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process.  This unit/process will manufacture heavier olefins with viscosities ranging from 4-6 Centistokes.  One flammable substance will be held over the threshold quantity - Propane (C3H8) used as a refrigerant.  One toxic substance is held over the threshold quantity - Boron Trifluoride (BF3) used as a catalyst. 

The Chocolate Bayou Site operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The facility has management representation 24 hours a day through the presence of a shift superintendent (4) and several working team leaders. One of the superintendents (name, email, and phone number listed in the registration part of this submission) is the main Emergency Contact, but any of the other three (3) Shift Superintendents are trained and able to take in the Emergency Contact responsibilities within the RMP. The phone number for the emergency contact is the same for all Shift Superintendents as they share the same office.

The LAO/PAO units will also operate 24 hours/day, 365 days/year.  Although the O&P Shift Superintendent will be the first contact in any emergency, they will coordinate with the Oligomers Operations

Manager in the event of an LAO/PAO unit emergency.  



Accidental Release Prevention Program
1.	Process Safety Information - The Chocolate Bayou Site maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to ensure the safe operation of the covered processes. SDS (Safety Data Sheets) document the physical properties of all hazardous substances handled in the site.  Engineering design documents include the safe operating parameters, design basis operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment of the covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards.  
2.	Process Hazard Analysis - The Chocolate Bayou Site performs and updates risk assessments of the covered processes to ensure systematic identification and control of process hazards.  These risk evaluations include off-site consequences as well as possible environment consequence and public impact.  Processes 1 to 7 use the What-If/Checklist analysis technique along with the Layer of Protection (LOPA) Analysis technique to perform these hazards evaluations. Process 8 and 9 uses the HAZOP/LOPA methodology to evaluate the risks that might be associated with this particular process.
3.	Operating Procedures - The Chocolate Bayou Site - Processes 1 to 7 maintains its operating procedures under the ISO9000 program.  As such, it is required to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operation are performed.  Operating procedures are used to train employees and contractors and they also serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during normal operations and process upsets. Process 8 and 9 have developed specific operating procedures.
4.	Training - To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Chocolate Bayou Site has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in chemical plant operations. After successfully comp
